Purpose: To visualize store traffic and customer movement in real-time using live camera feeds, enabling retailers to optimize store layout, staffing, and promotional strategies.
ExecSummary: Brick-and-mortar retailers often lack insights into in-store customer behavior, leading to inefficient layouts and missed sales opportunities. This live footfall heatmap agent leverages computer vision to capture movement patterns and inform real-time operational and strategic decisions.
ExecSummaryKeyAsks: Generate intuitive heatmaps for store zones
Use data to optimize staffing and layouts
Integrate analytics seamlessly with existing store systems
BusinessObjectives: Improve in-store shopper experience through layout optimization
Increase conversion rates by placing staff strategically
Reduce operational waste and queue delays
Make data-driven decisions on promotions and store planning
BusinessBenefits: 15-25% lift in conversion from better traffic flow
Optimize staffing schedules to match peak hours
Reduce time customers spend in queues by 20%
Enable evidence-based merchandising and campaign planning
overview: This demo showcases a live computer vision AI system that processes camera feeds to detect people, track movement patterns, and render real-time footfall heatmaps. Built on Python, OpenCV, and Flask, it offers visual analytics for store operations.
business: Retailers need deeper insights into how customers move through physical spaces to improve layout, restocking, promotions, and staffing. Manual observation is inconsistent and not scalable.
approach: The system ingests video feed from in-store cameras, runs real-time detection and tracking via OpenCV models, and aggregates positional data into heatmap layers. Insights are served through a Flask-based dashboard.
BusinessDrivers: Need for smarter, data-driven store operations
Reduce lost sales from understaffing or stockouts
Support agile store reconfiguration based on real data
BusinessChallanges: Limited visibility into physical customer behaviors
Inadequate manual methods for aisle or zone optimization
Difficulty adapting staff allocation in real-time
No easy integration between vision analytics and operations
FunctionalOverview: Footfall Detection: Detects and counts people in camera frames.
Zone Tracking: Monitors customer movement across predefined store zones.
Heatmap Generation: Aggregates traffic density into visual heatmaps.
Analytics Dashboard: Displays metrics, trends, and zone insights.
Alerting: Identifies unusually high footfall or queue build-ups.

FunctionalComponentDetails.Description: Uses OpenCV to detect and track individuals in live video streams.
KeyFeatures: Real-time multi-object tracking in crowded scenes
BusinessImpact: Provides accurate footfall data per zone
Enables live monitoring of customer movement
Lays foundation for store layout optimization

FunctionalComponentDetails.Description: Transforms tracking data into time-series heatmaps accessible via dashboard.

SolutionOverview: Live camera feed processed by OpenCV detection & tracking
Heatmap visualizations rendered via ECharts (or Flask UI)
Analytics served live through Flask dashboard
Supports integration with POS or staffing systems
dataflow: Live video streams feed into the detection engine, which identifies and tracks individual movement across zones. Aggregated positional data is processed into heatmap layers and sent to the Flask dashboard for visualization and alerting.
design: A modular microservice architecture using Python and OpenCV for detection/tracking, Flask for UI, and a lightweight data store to buffer zone metrics. Components support horizontal scaling across multiple stores.
